title: Lecture 0: Environment Setup
text:
üîß Setup Instructions

Option 1: Google Colab (Recommended for Beginners)

Click the ‚ÄúOpen in Colab‚Äù link above
Sign in with your Google account
You‚Äôre ready to go! No local installation needed



Option 2: Local Setup
# Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/jinming99/learn-ml-by-building.git
cd learn-ml-by-building

# Create virtual environment
python -m venv ml-env
source ml-env/bin/activate  # On Windows: ml-env\Scripts\activate

# Install requirements
pip install -r requirements.txt

# Launch Jupyter
jupyter notebook

title: Lecture 0: Environment Setup
text:
üí° Key Concepts

Why Environment Setup Matters

Reproducibility: Same code works for everyone
Package Management: Avoid version conflicts
Collaboration: Share code that others can run



Tools We‚Äôll Use Throughout the Course

NumPy: Numerical computing
Pandas: Data manipulation
Matplotlib/Seaborn: Visualization
Scikit-learn: Classical ML algorithms
PyTorch/TensorFlow: Deep learning

title: Lecture 0: Environment Setup

Python 3.8+ installed
Can run Jupyter notebooks
NumPy and Pandas import successfully
Can create basic plots with Matplotlib
GitHub repository cloned/accessible

title: Lecture 1: Welcome to Machine Learning
text: Welcome to Machine Learning! This course takes a unique ‚ÄúLearn by Building‚Äù approach where you‚Äôll implement real ML systems from day one. In today‚Äôs hands-on session, we‚Äôll explore the three fundamental paradigms of machine learning‚Äîsupervised, unsupervised, and active learning‚Äîby building CatShop, an e-commerce system that thinks like a cat using Google‚Äôs Gemma-3 language model.

title: Lecture 1: Welcome to Machine Learning
text:
Learning Objectives
By the end of this lecture, you will:

Experience all three ML paradigms through hands-on implementation
Fine-tune Gemma-3 (270M parameters) using LoRA for efficient adaptation
Observe catastrophic forgetting and model trade-offs
Build a complete ML application from data to deployment
Understand how active learning reduces labeling costs

title: Course Syllabus
text:
Course Description
Algorithms and principles involved in machine learning with applications to various engineering domains; fundamentals of representing uncertainty, learning from data, supervised learning, unsupervised learning, and learning theory; design and analysis of machine learning systems; design and implementation of a technical project applied to real-world datasets.

title: Course Syllabus
text:
Course Philosophy
This course embraces a ‚ÄúLearn ML by Building‚Äù philosophy:

Fundamentals First: Core concepts and unifying principles form the foundation
Scaffolded Learning: Progressive complexity with provided code skeletons
AI Portfolio: Build a collection of projects as mini research papers
Practical Impact: Bridge theory and application through hands-on implementation

title: Course Syllabus
text:
Course Learning Objectives
Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to:

Analyze and contrast broad classes of machine learning algorithms (supervised vs.¬†unsupervised)
Describe and apply fundamental concepts of learning from data (maximum likelihood estimation, maximum a posteriori, overfitting vs underfitting, regularization, cross-validation)
Design and implement supervised learning algorithms for regression and classification
Apply unsupervised learning algorithms for clustering and dimensionality reduction
Build and train neural networks using modern deep learning frameworks
Implement basic reinforcement learning agents
Evaluate ML systems for performance, fairness, and societal impact
Communicate complex ML concepts clearly through written reports and presentations

title: Course Syllabus
text:
Course Assessment

Grade Components (100 points total)








Component
Weight
Description




Project 1: Foundations
15%
KNN and fundamental principles


Project 2: Neural Networks
15%
Deep learning architectures & applications


Project 3: Reinforcement Learning
15%
Advanced topics (RL/GenAI)


Capstone Project
45%
Self-directed research project


Educational Content
5%
‚ÄúExplain ML to a Kid‚Äù videos (2 required)


Participation
5%
Piazza contributions, peer engagement


Flex/Adjustment
up to 5%
Reserved for bonus opportunities





Project Specifications

Format: Mini research papers following conference paper structure

Submission: PDF report via Canvas, code via GitHub

Collaboration: Individual work required for Projects 1-3
Capstone: Teams of 2-3 allowed with contribution statements



Late Policy

Three (3) free late days for the entire semester (use strategically)
After exhausting free days: 10% penalty per day
No late submissions accepted for final capstone project
Medical/emergency extensions require documentation through Dean of Students

title: Course Syllabus
text:
Course Policies

Academic Integrity
Virginia Tech Honor Code: ‚ÄúAs a Hokie, I will conduct myself with honor and integrity at all times. I will not lie, cheat, or steal, nor will I accept the actions of those who do.‚Äù
Specific to this course:

All submitted work must be your own or properly cited
Collaboration is encouraged for understanding concepts
Use of AI tools (ChatGPT, etc.) must be explicitly disclosed
Violations will result in a grade of F(0) for the assignment and referral to the Honor System



Attendance Policy

In-class activities may contribute to participation grade
Consistent absence may impact ability to succeed



Communication

Primary: Piazza for all course-related questions
Email: For personal/confidential matters only

Principles of Community
Virginia Tech is committed to creating an inclusive community that values diversity and seeks to promote an environment of mutual respect. Full statement

title: Machine Learning: Learn by Building
text:
This course takes a hands-on approach to machine learning. You‚Äôll:

Build real ML systems, not just study theory
Create an AI portfolio of mini research papers
Explain complex concepts simply (teaching = understanding)
Work with cutting-edge tools while mastering fundamentals

We believe the best way to understand machine learning is to build it, break it, and rebuild it better.

title: Projects Overview
text:
Project Reports

Format Requirements

Length: 3-5 pages (Projects 1-3), 6-8 pages (Capstone)
Structure:

Introduction & Problem Statement
Dataset Description
Methods & Implementation
Experiments & Results
Analysis & Discussion
Conclusion & Future Work

Code: Submit via GitHub links
Format: PDF via Canvas



Evaluation Criteria
Each project will be evaluated on:

Technical Implementation (40%)

Correctness of algorithms
Code quality and documentation
Appropriate use of libraries

Experimental Design (30%)

Systematic evaluation
Appropriate metrics
Hyperparameter tuning

Analysis & Insights (20%)

Understanding of results
Discussion of limitations
Bias-variance analysis where appropriate

Presentation (10%)

Clear writing
Effective visualizations
Proper citations

title: Projects Overview
text:

Teams of 2-3 students allowed for Projects 1-3
Individual work required for Capstone
Clear contribution statements required for team projects

title: Projects Overview
text:
Tips for Success






Best Practices




Start Early: ML projects always take longer than expected
Iterate: Your first model won‚Äôt be your best
Document: Keep notes on what you try and why
Visualize: A good plot is worth 1000 numbers
Collaborate: Discuss ideas, but write your own code

text:
Example Projects

Past Successful Projects

Image classification with CNNs on custom datasets
Time series prediction for energy consumption
Reinforcement learning for game playing
Text generation with fine-tuned transformers
Clustering analysis of social media data



Capstone Ideas

Apply ML to your research area
Reproduce and extend a recent paper
Create a novel dataset and benchmark
Combine multiple techniques for a complex problem
Build an interactive ML application

title: Capstone Project
text: The capstone project is your opportunity to conduct independent research in machine learning, applying everything you‚Äôve learned to a problem you‚Äôre passionate about. This individual project represents 45% of your course grade and culminates in a conference-style paper and presentation.

title: Capstone Project
text:
Detailed Rubrics & Guidelines






üìã Complete Rubrics Document



View Detailed Rubrics in Google Docs ‚Üí
This document contains: - Detailed grading criteria for each deliverable - Point breakdowns and weights - Submission requirements - Tips for success

title: Capstone Project
text:
Project Scope

Good Capstone Projects:

Applied ML: Apply ML to a novel domain or dataset
Reproduce & Extend: Replicate a recent paper and add improvements
Comparative Study: Systematic comparison of methods on new task
Tool/Library: Build a useful ML tool with documentation
Theory: Prove something about an algorithm or propose new method



Topic Selection Criteria:

Aligned with course content
Feasible in 3 weeks
Has clear evaluation metrics
Potential for interesting findings
Relates to your interests/research

title: Capstone Project
text:

NeurIPS Paper Template
How to Write a Good ML Paper

title: Capstone Project
text:
Submission Instructions

For All Deliverables:

Submit PDF via Canvas
Include GitHub repository link
Use NeurIPS/ICML format for reports
Name files: LastName_Capstone_[Deliverable].pdf



Code Repository Must Include:

README with setup instructions
Requirements file
Core implementation
Example notebook
Data preprocessing (if applicable)

title: Capstone Project
text:
FAQ
Q: Can I extend one of Projects 1-3?
A: Yes, but the extension must be substantial and clearly beyond the original scope.
Q: Can I use my research for the capstone?
A: Yes, with advisor approval and clear statement of your individual contribution.
Q: What if my project fails?
A: Negative results are valuable! Document what you tried, why it didn‚Äôt work, and what you learned.
Q: Can I collaborate with others?
A: You can discuss ideas, but implementation and writing must be individual. All discussions must be acknowledged.
Q: How much code is expected?
A: Quality over quantity. A well-documented, clean implementation of one algorithm is better than messy code for five.

title: Capstone Project
text:
Past Successful Projects
Examples of A-grade capstones from previous years:

‚ÄúPredicting Solar Panel Efficiency from Weather Data‚Äù - Applied various models, created useful tool
‚ÄúReproducing and Improving BERT for Low-Resource Languages‚Äù - Extended paper with new language
‚ÄúComparative Study of RL Algorithms on Custom Game Environment‚Äù - Built environment, tested 5 algorithms
‚ÄúNeural Architecture Search for Edge Devices‚Äù - Novel constraints, practical application
‚ÄúFairness Analysis of Admission Algorithms‚Äù - Important social impact, thorough analysis

title: Lecture 2: k-Nearest Neighbors
text: In this hands-on lecture, we tackle a real problem: finding compatible ML project teammates using k-Nearest Neighbors. Yes, you‚Äôll actually use this system to form your project teams! We‚Äôll explore how to frame real-world problems as ML tasks, understand the elegance of lazy learning, and confront the challenges of high-dimensional spaces.

title: Lecture 2: k-Nearest Neighbors
text:
Learning Objectives
By the end of this lecture, you will:

Frame real-world problems as ML tasks with inputs (X) and outputs (y)
Apply k-NN for classification and regression tasks
Analyze the impact of distance metrics and feature scaling
Understand the curse of dimensionality and its practical implications
Design fair and effective matching systems with domain constraints
Evaluate trade-offs between different similarity measures

title: Lecture 2: k-Nearest Neighbors
text:
Key Topics

The Data Journey: From text surveys ‚Üí NLP features ‚Üí 8D vectors
k-NN Fundamentals: The beautiful simplicity of ‚Äúyou are your neighbors‚Äù
Distance Metrics: Euclidean, Manhattan, Cosine, and when each matters
Curse of Dimensionality: When all points become equidistant
Fairness in ML: Ensuring inclusive team formation

title: Lecture 1: Welcome to Machine Learning
text: Welcome to Machine Learning! This course takes a unique ‚ÄúLearn by Building‚Äù approach where you‚Äôll implement real ML systems from day one. In today‚Äôs hands-on session, we‚Äôll explore the three fundamental paradigms of machine learning‚Äîsupervised, unsupervised, and active learning‚Äîby building CatShop, an e-commerce system that thinks like a cat using Google‚Äôs Gemma-3 language model.

title: Lecture 1: Welcome to Machine Learning
text:
Interactive Demo






üê± CatShop Web Application



Experience your trained model in action with the CatShop e-commerce demo, featuring real-time cat perspective classifications, confidence visualization, and interactive chat.
Built upon the WebShop environment with modifications for educational purposes.

text:
Acknowledgments & Resources

Core Technologies

Gemma-3 270M: Google‚Äôs efficient language model
PEFT/LoRA: Parameter-efficient fine-tuning
Transformers: Hugging Face‚Äôs model library



Dataset & Environment

WebShop: E-commerce product data and environment
Yao et al., ‚ÄúWebShop: Towards Scalable Real-World Web Interaction with Grounded Language Agents‚Äù, NeurIPS 2022
